This opinion piece is by Valarie Kaur, a civil rights lawyer, filmmaker, and interfaith leader who founded Groundswell, the nations largest multi-faith online organizing community.
Gunshots in a sanctuary of peace. C
continuation:
ries of pain and anguish. A call to action.
These are the sounds of the past week and a half, as we mourn the loss of life in a mass shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, and as we respond to the pain and grief of our Muslim brothers and sisters.
On March 15, 2019, a lone gunman opened fire at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, killing 50 people and injuring dozens more. The shooter livestreamed the attack on Facebook, which has since been taken down.
The massacre was the deadliest attack on Muslims in New Zealands history, and it was the deadliest attack on any faith in New Zealands history.
In the aftermath of the attack, New Zealands Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern declared a state of emergency and called for a national day of mourning. She also called for a ban on the sale of semi-automatic weapons.
The day of mourning was followed by a series of events in Christchurch, including a vigil for the victims, a march to Parliament, and a candlelight vigil at the Al Noor mosque.
These events were held in solidarity with the Muslim community in New Zealand and around the world.

input: Red Hat bought IT automation-centric configuration management DevOps-friendly firm Ansible, okay so we know that part. Retaining the Ansible brand and names as it does, this month sees Red Hat launch Ansible Container, but what is
continuation:
it?

Ansible Container is a container orchestration and automation platform that provides a set of tools to help developers and IT teams build and deploy containerized applications.

Its not the first time weve heard of Red Hat and Ansible. In fact, Red Hat has been a major Ansible user for years, with the company using Ansible to build, deploy, manage, and secure its OpenShift container platform.

Ansible Container is based on Ansible, but it is a bit more advanced than the original Ansible. It provides the ability to run containers on Kubernetes and Docker, but it also has support for Docker Swarm, Docker Compose, and Docker Compose Express.

Its also got the ability to use Docker Compose to create containers that can run on Kubernetes. This means that you can build containerized applications that run on Kubernetes and Docker, and you can deploy them to Docker Swarm, Docker Compose, or Docker Compose Express.

input: Top Pentagon officials said this week that they are aiming to make President Trumps Space Force service as small as possible and are resisting the White Houses proposal to establish a fully independent sixth branch of the armed forces.
continuation:

That may be a mistake, say advice providers, who
continuation:
say they want to be there to help clients make the best financial decisions.
We need to step in and help clients make the right decisions, said Michael C. Kucera, president of Kucera Financial, a wealth management firm based in New Jersey. Theres a lot of confusion.
Kucera and his colleagues at Kucera Financial have been talking with companies that want to automate their employee-benefits plans. The goal, he said, is to help employees make better financial choices.
Were trying to get a better understanding of what theyre doing, he said. We want to help them make better decisions about what theyre putting into their plan.
Kucera Financial is one of a growing number of companies that want to help employees make better financial decisions.
A recent survey from the Employee Benefit Research Institute found that 70 percent of employers plan to offer automatic enrollment in retirement plans, and 63 percent of employers plan to offer a one-stop life-cycle fund.
The survey also found that most employers plan to use one-stop funds to help employees save for retirement.

Fisher was one of the most important people in the history of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
He helped bring the Indianapolis 500 back to Indianapolis after it was canceled in 1932 because of World War II. He was instrumental in bringing the Indianapolis 500 to the United States for the first time in 1967.

continuation:
that can occur when a persons heart stops beating.

The device, which was implanted in the upper chest of a 60-year-old man, is the first of its kind in the U.S. and is designed to deliver a shock to the heart to restore its normal rhythm.

This is a life-saving device that can save a life, said Dr. John H. Lohman, chairman of the department of cardiovascular medicine at Penn Medicine, who led the implantation of the device. The device is designed to deliver a shock to the heart to restore its normal rhythm, and it can have a dramatic effect on a persons quality of life.

ICD is a small, battery-powered device that delivers a shock to the heart to restore its normal rhythm. A defibrillator is a device that delivers a shock to the heart to restart the hearts normal rhythm.

Sudden cardiac arrest occurs when the heart stops beating for a brief period of time. It is the leading cause of death in the U.S., killing more than 50,000 people each year.

input: NEW YORK  One recent spring morning in the Utah desert, Jerry Foote received an ecstatic e-mail that gravitational forces were causing two stars to orbit each other, with one star swallowing matter from its companion. Rudolf Novak received the same message
continuation:
, but it was from a different source.

Foote, a physicist at the University of California, Berkeley, and Novak, an astrophysicist at the University of California, Santa Cruz, were two of the first scientists to detect gravitational waves, the ripples in space-time caused by the merging of two black holes.

It was a very exciting day, Foote said. It was like, Wow, weve discovered something.

The discovery of gravitational waves, which was reported in the journal Nature on Wednesday, has opened up a new frontier in physics. Scientists have known for decades that black holes can create ripples in space-time, but the first time they were detected, in 2015, scientists were not sure what to make of them.

Its been a long time coming, Novak said. The first time they were detected, we thought, Oh, theyre just noise.

TRUCKEE, Calif.  Property owners this week overwhelmingly approved a special tax to fund maintenance for the Brickelltown streetscape project.
At Tuesdays Truckee Town Council meeting, returned mailed ballots (30 out of 34
continuation:
) showed support for the tax, which will be levied on property owners in the Brickelltown area.
If approved by voters, the tax will be charged on the assessed value of property in the area, and will be paid by property owners.
The tax will be assessed at $4 per $100,000 of assessed value, and will be levied on property owners in Brickelltown, the Village of Truckee, and Truckee Meadows Community College.
The tax is expected to generate about $1.5 million per year, which will be used to maintain the streetscape project.
The streetscape project will include the installation of sidewalks, street lights, landscaping, and other amenities.
The project will also improve the pedestrian experience in the area, with the installation of a new pedestrian crossing at the intersection of Brickell Avenue and South Truckee Boulevard.
The project is expected to be completed by the end of the year.
For more information on the Brickelltown streetscape project, visit the project website at https://www.truckeetown.org/brickelltown-streetscape/.

The gritty streets of this 4-by-12-block sliver of a town in densely populated and urbanized northern Hudson County might be the last place to expect to find a largely volunteer fire department.
Such departments are usually associated with small-
continuation:
town America, where people are often friendly and the local fire department is a family affair.
But in this part of the world, the volunteer fire department is a big business.
"It's a family affair," said Fire Chief Joseph D'Agostino. "You know it's a family business."
The Hudson County Volunteer Fire Department, which covers a four-square-mile area, has more than 500 members, including firefighters, paramedics, dispatchers, administrative staff and volunteers.
The department is a non-profit, but it pays for its equipment, including its trucks and engines. It also pays for its own maintenance and repairs, and for fuel.
D'Agostino said the department's budget is about $1 million a year.
"It's a very expensive department," he said.
The department's budget is funded by a variety of sources, including a $400,000 grant from the state, a $250,000 grant from the federal government, and about $500,000 from donations.
The department is also supported by the county, which pays about $1.5 million a year for the department's services.

Tennessee's state-run Achievement School District, which takes over low-performing schools and either runs them directly or hands them over to charter organizations, has run into partisan political trouble.
Several Democratic state lawmakers say they will propose bills this upcoming legislative
continuation:
session that would prohibit the state from running Achievement School District schools. They say the state is spending too much money on the schools.
"It's not just about the money. It's about the fact that the state is taking over a failing school system," said state Sen. John Ragan, D-Nashville. "It's not fair to taxpayers. It's not fair to the kids. And it's not fair to the parents."
Ragan said he will introduce a bill that would bar the state from taking over failing schools, and another that would prohibit the state from giving control of Achievement School District schools to a charter organization. He said he expects the bills to be introduced in the next few months.
"We're going to have to get a lot of support from the Republican caucus to get these bills passed," Ragan said. "But I think it's important that we take a hard look at this."

input: Senate President Chuck Morse has a plan to absorb a nearly $30 million budget shortfall created by a lawsuit over hospital payments. But it could come at the expense of a host of other legislative priorities, potentially putting spending bills in jeopardy, he said Monday.
continuation:

Im not going to do it unless Im assured that the states not going to have to dip into the rainy day fund, Morse said. I dont want to do it without that assurance.

The family of the limousine driver involved in a deadly crash in upstate New York says they believe he was unwittingly assigned an unsafe vehicle.
The family of Scott Lisinicchia released a statement through their lawyer Tuesday asking the public to not
continuation:
rush to judgment about the crash.
Lisinicchia was driving a stretch limousine with six people on board when it crashed in Schoharie, New York, on Saturday. Five of the passengers, including four teenagers, died.
The familys lawyer, Robert Eglet, said the limousine had been assigned to Lisinicchias family for a birthday party.
The lawyer said the limousine was equipped with air bags and seatbelts, but the passengers did not wear them.
Eglet said the family believes Lisinicchia was unaware of the safety features of the vehicle.
The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the crash.

A woman sucker punched and stabbed on the subway says the attack was motivated by hate. Wale Aliyu reports.
A woman was punched and stabbed when she got off the subway in Brooklyn by a man yelling racially charged words, her family and
continuation:
police said.
The incident happened around 7:30 p.m. on Monday, Feb. 4, on the 3 train at the Atlantic Avenue-Barclays Center station, according to the NYPD.
The woman, 21, was riding the train with a group of friends when she was approached by a man who was yelling racial slurs, police said.
The woman, who is African-American, said the man then punched her in the face and stabbed her in the back, police said.
The man then fled the train, according to police.
The victim was taken to Kings County Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, police said.
The victim's brother, Wale Aliyu, said his sister was attacked because of her race.
"He was just screaming racial slurs at her," Aliyu said. "He was yelling, 'I'm going to kill you, I'm going to kill you.' "
Aliyu said the man was wearing a dark hooded sweatshirt and dark pants.
Police are investigating the attack.

Today's Millennials could be tomorrow's very sweaty retirees thanks to temperatures and humidity levels that are rising so fast that, by the end of this century, simply going outside could be deadly.
The study's alarming findings put into sharp perspective not just what
continuation:
's happening to our planet but also to the people who live there.
"It's really important to think about what's going to happen to the people who live in these places," said Dr. Robert Langer, director of the University of Washington's Population and Environmental Health Research Center.
"We're going to have a lot of people who are going to be really sweaty, who are going to have a lot of problems with their health, who are going to have a lot of health problems as a result of climate change," he said.
Langer's study, published in the journal Science Advances, looked at how climate change will affect the health of the more than 1.5 billion people who live in the world's poorest countries.

Defensive back K'Waun Williams, shown after making a big play for the Pitt Panthers last season, has signed with the Cleveland Browns.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The Browns continue to add to their cornerback pile.
On Tuesday,
continuation:
the team announced it had signed free-agent cornerback K'Waun Williams.
Williams, a former Pitt standout, was selected by the Washington Redskins in the fourth round of the 2018 NFL Draft. He spent last season on the Redskins' practice squad.
"We're excited to add K'Waun to our roster," Browns general manager Andrew Berry said in a statement. "He brings great size, length and athleticism to our secondary. We look forward to his contributions to our defense."
Williams is the third cornerback the Browns have signed this offseason. They also signed former Pittsburgh Steelers cornerback Cameron Sutton and former Cincinnati Bengals cornerback Darqueze Dennard.
Sutton and Dennard are expected to compete for the No. 3 cornerback job behind Denzel Ward and Greedy Williams.

input: What were the politics of abortion like in this country before Roe v. Wade? Different than what I thought in a couple of important ways, Ive learned from a new book, Before Roe v. Wade, by Linda Greenhouse and Rev
continuation:
. James Dobson.

Greenhouse and Dobson, who have known each other for more than 40 years, have written a book that is a history of the abortion debate in the United States.

Before Roe v. Wade was written in 1973, abortion was illegal in all 50 states. There were few clinics, and the procedure was usually performed by a doctor in a hospital or a doctors office.

Abortion was not legal in the U.S. until 1973, when the Supreme Court ruled in Roe v. Wade that a womans right to an abortion was protected under the 14th Amendment.

In this book, Greenhouse and Dobson explain the evolution of the abortion debate.

It was very different than what we see today, Greenhouse said. There were very few clinics, and the procedure was usually performed by a doctor in a hospital or a doctors office.

Paparazzi who took photographs of Princess Diana dying in a car wreck stopped police from getting to the scene, her inquest heard today.
Eyewitness Clifford Goorovadoo said: "It is true that when the first police officers
continuation:
arrived on the scene they were told by the paparazzi that the princess had died.
"They did not want the police to get to the scene because they were afraid that the paparazzi would take photographs of the princess."
Mr Goorovadoo, who was with his wife at the time of the crash, said he was told by police that the princess had died.
He said: "They said that Diana had died.
"I was told that the police were afraid that paparazzi would take photographs of the princess.
"I did not know what to do.
"I was told that the police were afraid that they would not be able to get to the scene of the accident because of the paparazzi.
"I did not know what to do.

input: DES MOINES, Iowa (AP)  Authorities apprehended a man Wednesday suspected in the early morning killings of two Des Moines area police officers who were shot to death while sitting in their patrol cars in what authorities described as separate ambush-style attacks.
continuation:
The suspect was identified as De'Von Bailey, 23, who was arrested without incident in a wooded area outside the Des Moines suburb of Ankeny.

The suspect was being held in the Polk County Jail in Des Moines on two counts of first-degree murder and one count of attempted first-degree murder, according to the Polk County Sheriff's Office.

Des Moines Police Sgt. Paul Parizek and Sgt. Paul Parizek were shot and killed Tuesday morning as they sat in their patrol cars in a parking lot at the police department's headquarters. Sgt. Paul Parizek was shot in the head and died at the scene.

Sgt. Matthew Jones was shot in the arm and was taken to a hospital, where he was listed in stable condition.

"We're going to get through this," Des Moines Mayor Frank Cownie said at a news conference. "We're going to get through this because we have a strong community. We're going to get through this because we have a strong police department. We're going to get through this because we have a strong sheriff's department. We're going to get through this because we have a strong prosecutor's office."

continuation:
the wreckage of the world's longest-running shipwreck.

The search for the plane, which disappeared on March 8, 2014, has been plagued by poor weather and delays, but Australian officials say they are confident they are close to finding the wreckage.

"We are confident that we will find the aircraft," Australian Transport Minister Darren Chester said.

The search for the Boeing 777-200ER was launched in January 2014 after the plane's last known location was traced to a remote part of the Indian Ocean.

Chester said the sonar search, which has covered an area of 1,000 square kilometers (380 square miles), had failed to spot the plane.

"We have not found the aircraft," he said. "But we are confident that we will find the aircraft."

THOUSAND OAKS, CA (RNN) - Less than two weeks after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting that killed 11, another mass shooting has taken a dozen lives in California.
A gunman killed 12 people, including a sheriffs
continuation:
deputy, at the Borderline Bar & Grill in Thousand Oaks on Wednesday night.
The shooter, identified as Ian David Long, opened fire at the bar around 11:30 p.m. local time, according to the Ventura County Sheriffs Office.
Long was identified as a 21-year-old white man from Newbury Park, California, according to reports.
The sheriffs office said he had a long history of mental illness, according to the Ventura County Star.
Long was arrested at the scene and has been charged with murder, attempted murder, assault with a semiautomatic firearm, possession of a firearm by a felon, and possession of a firearm by a prohibited person, according to the Ventura County Sheriffs Office.
He is being held without bail at the Ventura County Jail, according to the Ventura County Sheriffs Office website.
A motive for the shooting has not yet been released.
This is a developing story. Please check back for updates.

input: Former Kent State wrestling coach Ron Gray will be inducted into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame on June 1 in Stillwater, Okla. Gray, who coached the Golden Flashes for 25 seasons, is one of four members who will be inducted
continuation:
into the Hall of Fame this year.

Gray, a native of Kent, Ohio, was a four-time All-American at Kent State and was a member of the schools first national championship team in 1985. He was inducted into the Kent State Athletics Hall of Fame in 2005.

Grays coaching career started at Kent State in 1974, where he was an assistant coach. He was promoted to head coach in 1978 and led the Flashes to the NCAA Division II national title in 1981.

Gray went on to coach at Ohio State University, where he coached the Buckeyes to the schools first national championship in 1988. He led the Buckeyes to four consecutive NCAA Division II national titles from 1989-92.

Grays final coaching job was at the University of Toledo, where he coached the Rockets to back-to-back NCAA Division II national titles in 2000 and 2001.

Grays induction into the National Wrestling Hall of Fame is one of the highlights of his career.

QUITO, ECUADOREcuador election officials have agreed to recount nearly 1.3 million votes as opposition leader Guillermo Lasso continues to allege fraud in the presidential election.
The National Electoral Council announced late Thursday it would
continuation:
conduct a recount of votes cast in the April 11 election.
The council said the recount will be carried out over the next few days.
Lasso has alleged fraud in the vote count and has called for a new election.
The electoral council has said it will not change the result of the election.
Lasso won 51 per cent of the vote in the first round of the election.

A Tesco petrol station near Cambridge was raided today (February 28) by masked men, triggering a major police response.
Two men wearing hoods and masks were reported to have broken into the station at the Milton Tesco on Cambridge Road.
continuation:
A large police cordon was put in place, and officers from Cambridgeshire Police were called to the scene.
The men were last seen running from the scene.
A spokesman for Cambridgeshire Police said: "We were called to a report of a break-in at a Tesco store in Milton, Cambridgeshire, this morning.
"Two men wearing hoods and masks were reported to have broken into the store at around 8.30am.
"The men were last seen running from the scene.
"Enquiries are ongoing and anyone with information is asked to call police on 101, quoting incident number 481 of 28 February."
Anyone with information can also contact Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

Texas has become the first state in the nation to require law enforcement to obtain a warrant to read people's email, and privacy advocates are hoping the move will help quicken the passage of a similar proposal in Congress.
Texas Gov. Rick Perry signed
continuation:
the bill into law on Monday, making it the first state in the nation to require law enforcement to obtain a warrant to read people's email. The law, which takes effect in July, also requires law enforcement to keep a record of all emails they receive and delete them if they are no longer relevant to an investigation.
The law also requires law enforcement officers to notify people of their right to be silent and to obtain a warrant if it's necessary to read their emails.
"This is a step in the right direction," said John W. Whitehead, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, which supported the bill. "It is a very important step."
The bill was sponsored by state Sen. Lois Kolkhorst, R-Houston, and passed the Texas Senate in May. It passed the Texas House of Representatives in May by a vote of 105-5.
The bill's sponsor, state Sen. Lois Kolkhorst, R-Houston, said in a statement that the bill "will help ensure that law enforcement is not reading people's emails in the privacy of their homes."

In an increasingly digital economy, banks are becoming more dependent on efficient data processing to improve customer service and products, and ensure
continuation:
compliance with regulations.
But while the data that banks collect is becoming increasingly valuable, the tools they use to process it are becoming increasingly complex.
For instance, in the US, the Federal Reserve has been developing a set of standards to govern the processing of customer data, which is expected to be finalized in the next few years.
The Fed plans to release the standards, which will be based on the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), in the fall of 2017.

input: (Newser)  The US is still flying Boeing 737 Max 8 planes, despite a growing number of nations grounding them following two crashes in less than five months. (NPR is keeping track of the countries and airlines that have grounded the planes so far
continuation:
.)

The FAA is still requiring pilots to follow new flight-control software, which has been implicated in both crashes, and the FAA is still certifying the planes to be flown, reports the Wall Street Journal. "In the wake of the second crash, the FAA said it would conduct a 'thorough review' of the software," the Journal adds. "The agency is also working with the European Union Aviation Safety Agency to determine if the same software is implicated in the crashes."

Daniel R. Welsh, 60, of Williamsfield, OH, died Sunday, October 20, 2013, at his home.
Born March 22, 1953, in Pittsburgh, a son of Shirley L. (Gregory) Vidonic, Aliqu
continuation:
ippa, PA, and the late Robert T. Welsh.
He was a 1971 graduate of Aliquippa High School.
He was a member of St. Paul Lutheran Church, Williamsfield.
Daniel worked as a truck driver for several years.
He was a member of the Williamsfield Fire Department.
He enjoyed hunting, fishing, camping, and spending time with his family.
He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Linda A. Welsh of Williamsfield; two sons, Michael Welsh of Williamsfield and Mark Welsh of Williamsfield; two brothers, Robert T. Welsh of Williamsfield and James L. Welsh of Florida; a sister, Judy M. (Bill) Smith of Williamsfield; a sister-in-law, Mary Ann Welsh of Williamsfield; and several nieces and nephews.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by a brother, Robert T. Welsh, Jr.
Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday, October 26, 2013, at St. Paul Lutheran Church, Williamsfield, with the Rev. John K. Smith officiating.
Burial will be in St. Paul Lutheran Cemetery, Williamsfield.

Gabrielle Lyons was asking for $750,000 from the university in a lawsuit she
continuation:
filed in 2015, claiming that it failed to take care of Grotberg, who was hit by a car as he walked across the street.
Grotberg, 20, was pronounced dead at Baylor Medical Center in Waco, Texas, after being hit by a car on Feb. 4, 2015.
Lyons lawsuit claimed that Baylor failed to take care of Grotberg, who had been diagnosed with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and an eating disorder.
The university settled the lawsuit in 2017, agreeing to pay $1.5 million, according to the Waco Tribune-Herald.
Lyons, who was not named in the lawsuit, said in a court filing that Grotberg was hit by a car that was driving erratically, and that she didnt know the driver of the car.
Grotberg had been walking across the street with a friend when he was hit, the lawsuit said.
Lyons said in her filing that she learned that the driver of the car that hit Grotberg was a Baylor student who had recently moved to Waco.
Lyons said she wanted Baylor to pay for Grotbergs funeral, as well as his mental health care.

continuation:

WhileComcast had its problems in 2015, its Universal Pictures segment had an unprecedented year specifically with franchise films.
It's not that other segments of the business struggled. Cable was strong, despite cord-cutting fears, and even
continuation:
the sports business was strong, with the NFL and the NBA in particular doing well.
But the Universal Pictures segment, which includes movies like Jurassic World, The Fate of the Furious, and Fifty Shades Darker, was the main driver of Comcast's top-line growth and profitability in 2015.
That's according to a new report from MoffettNathanson analyst Michael Nathanson, who said that Comcast's Universal Pictures segment generated $3.3 billion in box office revenue in 2015, which is up from $2.8 billion in 2014 and $2.1 billion in 2013.
That growth was due in part to the strong performance of Jurassic World, which generated $1.1 billion in box office revenue in 2015, and The Fate of the Furious, which generated $1.4 billion in box office revenue in 2015.
"Universal Pictures was the star of the show in 2015," Nathanson wrote in a note to clients. "It was the only major studio to generate more than $1 billion in box office revenue in 2015, and it was the only major studio that generated more than $2 billion in box office revenue in 2015."

A judge ruled on Monday that the state of Massachusetts cannot sue the federal government for expanding a religious exemption to the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive mandate.
"While we are disappointed in this decision, we remain steadfast in our commitment to ensuring affordable and reliable
continuation:
access to contraception for all women," Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey said in a statement. "We will continue to work with our federal partners to ensure that all women have access to affordable and reliable access to contraception."
The decision, by U.S. District Court Judge Allison D. Burroughs in Boston, comes after Healey's office sued the Trump administration last year, arguing that the administration violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act by excluding religious employers from the contraceptive mandate.
The lawsuit was the first of its kind in the country, and the decision means that the federal government will no longer be able to enforce the mandate in Massachusetts.
Healey's office argued that the administration's exclusion of religious employers from the mandate violates the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which protects religious organizations from being forced to violate their beliefs in order to receive government benefits.
"This is a significant victory for religious liberty in America," Healey said in a statement. "The federal government should not be able to coerce religious organizations into violating their religious beliefs in order to receive government benefits."
Healey's office is now pursuing an appeal of the decision.

input: SPRINGFIELD -- The Department of Children and Family Services began issuing layoff notices to 600 employees on Friday with the aim of paring its workforce by 375 positions while still meeting its legal obligations to care for abused and neglected children and provide other services
continuation:
.

The department said it will begin laying off employees in the next few weeks, with the goal of reaching the goal of cutting 375 positions by the end of the year.

"It's a difficult process," said DCFS Commissioner MaryEllen Elia. "We're not looking to eliminate jobs. We're not looking to cut people's hours. We're not looking to cut their pay. We're not looking to cut their benefits. We're not looking to do anything that's going to hurt people."

The department said it will work with affected employees to find other positions within the agency.

"We'll be looking at every position," Elia said. "We'll be looking at every job, and we'll be looking at every job as an opportunity for us to improve."

input: I remember the first interview I did about the gender pay gap, back in the 90s, when women had their very own Equal Opportunities Commission. We talked about pay rates reaching parity in full-time work, then getting dragged down by part-
continuation:
time work.

input: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Ra Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (NASDAQ:RARX) today announced that the design of its Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized my
continuation:
asthenia gravis (GMG) has been initiated. The trial will evaluate the efficacy and safety of RA101495 SC in combination with standard-of-care (SOC) therapies in patients with GMG.

We are pleased to announce the initiation of our Phase 2 clinical trial of RA101495 SC for the treatment of generalized myasthenia gravis (GMG), said David J. Cohen, M.D., Ph.D., Chief Executive Officer of Ra Pharmaceuticals. We believe that RA101495 SC may be a potential treatment option for patients with GMG who have failed to respond to SOC therapies.

GMR is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by progressive inflammation of the myasthenia gravis muscle. The disease is associated with the presence of antibodies in the blood, leading to progressive muscle weakness, fatigue, and fatigue-like symptoms.

There is a hearing today on whether presidents should be required to make their tax returns public.
Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., then incoming chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, addressed an audience, Nov. 27, during a gathering
continuation:
of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee in Washington, D.C. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)
WASHINGTON (JTA)  U.S. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal, D-Mass., will hold a hearing Wednesday on whether presidents should be required to make their tax returns public.
Neal, who is expected to be re-elected to the post in November, will hold the hearing at 11 a.m. ET at the House office building in Washington, D.C., according to the committees website.
The hearing comes amid a heated debate over whether President Donald Trump should be required to release his tax returns, which he has long refused to do.
The House Ways and Means Committee, which Neal chairs, passed a resolution in May calling for Trump to release his tax returns.
Trump has not released his tax returns since his election in November 2016.
The president has said he is under audit by the Internal Revenue Service, which has not responded to a request for comment from JTA.

continuation:
political purposes.

Organizers of the caravan said they had reached a key point in the journey, where they expect to be able to cross into Mexico.

The migrants, many of whom are from Honduras, said they had stopped at a plaza in the southern city of Tapachula to rest after a long day of walking. They said they would continue walking until they reached the border, where they would apply for asylum.

We are a group of people who are fleeing violence, he said. We dont want to be terrorists.

Valejah Savon Johnson's argument with Robert Mayes resulted in Mayes clinging to the hood of Johnson's speeding pickup truck, according to affidavit.
LAFAYETTE Twenty-one-year-old Valejah Savon Johnson
continuation:
, of Lafayette, was arrested Wednesday after police said he got into an argument with a man in a pickup truck and tried to hit him.
Johnson was arrested on charges of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, criminal mischief and resisting arrest.
Police were called to the 100 block of West Fourth Street around 6:45 p.m. Wednesday for an argument between Johnson and Robert Mayes.
Police said Mayes was sitting in the driver's seat of a pickup truck when Johnson got in the passenger seat and tried to hit him.
Johnson allegedly tried to hit Mayes three times before he got out of the truck and tried to walk away.
Mayes was able to hold onto the hood of Johnson's pickup truck, according to the affidavit.
Police said Johnson then tried to run away, but Mayes was able to catch him.
Mayes told police that Johnson hit him in the face with his fist, but Johnson denied that, according to the affidavit.
Johnson was booked into the Lafayette Parish Correctional Center. He is being held on a $10,000 bond.

PULGA  In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.
Six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou
continuation:
-to-Palo Verde transmission line that runs through the Sierra Nevada foothills is still in shambles.
This is a failure of the system, PG&Es chief executive, Bill Johnson, told a state Senate committee last week. Its not a failure of the technology. Its not a failure of the equipment. Its not a failure of the people who work on it. Its a failure of the system.
PG&Es problem is that the companys transmission lines are too old and too vulnerable to the forces of nature. The companys transmission lines are so old and so vulnerable to the forces of nature that the company has had to spend billions of dollars just to keep them running.
Thats why PG&Es transmission lines have been so critical to the Camp Fires devastation. The fire, which began on Nov. 8, scorched an area the size of Los Angeles, killed 85 people and destroyed more than 18,000 homes.

Polands ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate supreme court judges it forcibly retired, acting on an injunction issued by Europes highest court.
On Wednesday the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted the relevant legislation on
continuation:
the issue to parliament.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg had ruled in March that the PiS government had broken the law by forcibly removing judges from their posts.
The ECHR said the judges had been illegally removed and had not been given an opportunity to defend themselves.
Polands supreme court had ordered the reinstatement of the judges, but the government said it would go ahead with the move anyway.
The ECHR said the Polish government had failed to justify its decision to remove the judges.
The governments move to reinstate the judges was the latest in a series of moves by the PiS government that has raised concerns in the West about the erosion of judicial independence in Poland.
The PiS government, which came to power in 2015, has also introduced a law on judicial reform that it says is needed to combat corruption.
But critics say the law, which would remove some judicial independence, is part of a broader attempt by PiS to tighten its grip on the judiciary.
The European Commission, the EUs executive arm, has warned Poland that it could face legal action over the judicial reforms.

Security always comes down to securing applications.
The whole point of firewalls is to hide internally deployed network applicationsassumed to have exploitable vulnerabilities somewherefrom the outside world.
The main weakness of firewalls is that they are
continuation:
a network security tool, not a network access control tool. They are meant to protect the network from outside attacks, not the other way around.
The best way to protect applications is to secure them. This is why network access control (NAC) software is so important.
Network access control software is a set of rules and policies that govern the movement of users and data across the network. It's a way to prevent malicious users from accessing sensitive data or endpoints.
NAC software is used in the following ways:
To restrict access to specific applications on a network.

A GP clinic in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away.
The changes at the Links Medical Centre come into force on Wednesday, May 1.
A statement
continuation:
from the centre said: "As part of our ongoing efforts to reduce the number of people visiting the clinic in the future, we are introducing a telephone assessment system on a three-day a week basis.
"This will allow us to better manage the current waiting times for patients with non-urgent appointments.
"We would like to thank our patients for their patience and understanding as we make these changes.
"This is a temporary measure which will be reviewed at the end of the three-day assessment period.
"We apologise for any inconvenience this may cause.
"We would like to reassure our patients that we will continue to provide a full range of medical services at the Links Medical Centre."

continuation:
technology.

Huawei, the world's biggest producer of telecoms equipment, has come under pressure from the U.S. government and some European governments to be excluded from next-generation 5G networks because of fears that it could be used by Beijing to spy on communications.

The U.S. government has also accused Huawei of stealing trade secrets. Huawei has repeatedly denied the allegations.

The Seattle area has a new biotechnology company -- and this one is going to try attacking cancer by examining antibodies instead of tumors.
Johnny Stine, founder and chief scientist of the new Spaltudaq Corp., said the approach, if it
continuation:
works, could have a big impact on cancer treatment.

"We're going to look at cancer cells and see if we can find a way to break them down so they can't get into the body," Stine said. "We're going to look at the immune system and see if we can get rid of the cancer cells so they can't do anything."

Stine, a cancer researcher at the University of Washington School of Medicine, said the company is moving quickly to develop the technology, which is known as antibody-drug conjugates.

"We're not going to wait for the FDA to approve it," Stine said. "We're going to go ahead and do it."

Stine said the company plans to file for FDA approval by the end of the year.

The company is working with the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, which is providing a $1 million grant to help with the development of the technology.

"It's going to be a game-changer," Stine said. "It's going to be the most important thing in medicine in the next 20 years."

The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch of the freeway that runs between the cities of Pasadena and Glendale.

The freeway is named in honor of the 44th president, who was born in Hawaii and lived in the Los Angeles area for more than a decade.

WASHINGTON  Republican David Yancey won a drawing to break a tie in the disputed 94th District race in Newport News Thursday however his opponent is expected to challenge the decision, possibly seeking yet another recount.
Control of the House of Delegates is
continuation:
at stake in Thursdays election, with Democrats needing a net gain of 23 seats to take control of the chamber. Republicans need to hold onto 23 seats to maintain their majority.
Yancey, a Newport News city councilman, defeated Democratic challenger and former Virginia Beach Mayor Mike Signer by a margin of 5,844 votes out of nearly 1.5 million cast.
Yancey, who has served in the state House of Delegates since 2014, was declared the winner by the Virginia State Board of Elections after a recount.
Signers campaign has filed a lawsuit in federal court to challenge the results.
